title: Official Blind Review #2
review:
The authors propose creating new classes for augmented data instead of the traditional approach of adding them to the original source class. The hope is that a more diverse set of tasks will be created, thus better approximating some unseen task in few-shot learning. They test this idea by rotating images to augment the data and then compare the two approaches. Their experiments were conducted using several data sets and a few different base learners. In nearly all the results, they show that their approach performs better. 

I find Figure 3 difficult to read because of the separation of the 1-shot and 5-shot classes. (The figure feels a bit clumsy to read.) I'm also unclear what that section contributes to the paper since it is so short. 

Why only use rotations to augment?

I weakly accept this paper because the simple idea seems elegant and appears to improve performance. Since I know little about the field, I will defer to other, more qualified reviewers. I would like to see more experimentation though since this is purely an experimental paper (theory would be wonderful).
